strategy: Experiment with Neural Networks: Utilize a neural network architecture such as a deep learning model like a multi-layer perceptron or a convolutional neural network if applicable. This can leverage complex non-linear relationships and provide a strong baseline for comparison.

actions.action:
cat << 'ENDOFFILE' > train_and_predict.py
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.neural_network import MLPRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Combine train and test sets for preprocessing
combined = pd.concat([train, test], ignore_index=True)

# Drop unnecessary columns
columns_to_drop = ['Id', 'SalePrice']
y = combined['SalePrice'].dropna()
X = combined.drop(columns=columns_to_drop)

# Handle missing values
X.fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

# Encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X)

# Scale numerical features
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

# Split back into train and test sets
X_train = X_scaled[:len(train)]
X_test = X_scaled[len(train):]

# Define the model
nn_model = MLPRegressor(hidden_layer_sizes=(100,), max_iter=500, random_state=42)

# Train the model
nn_model.fit(X_train, y)

# Make predictions
predictions = nn_model.predict(X_test)

# Save predictions to submission.csv
submission = pd.DataFrame({'Id': test['Id'], 'SalePrice': predictions})
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
ENDOFFILE

cat << 'ENDOFFILE' > train_and_predict.py
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.neural_network import MLPRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Combine train and test sets for preprocessing
combined = pd.concat([train, test], ignore_index=True)

# Drop unnecessary columns
columns_to_drop = ['Id', 'SalePrice']
y = combined['SalePrice'].dropna()
X = combined.drop(columns=columns_to_drop)

# Handle missing values
X.fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

# Encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X)

# Scale numerical features
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

# Split back into train and test sets
X_train = X_scaled[:len(train)]
X_test = X_scaled[len(train):]

# Define the model
nn_model = MLPRegressor(hidden_layer_sizes=(100,), max_iter=500, random_state=42)

# Train the model
nn_model.fit(X_train, y)

# Make predictions
predictions = nn_model.predict(X_test)

# Debug print to check the shape and contents of predictions
print("Predictions shape:", predictions.shape)
print("Predictions sample:", predictions[:5])

# Save predictions to submission.csv
submission = pd.DataFrame({'Id': test['Id'], 'SalePrice': predictions})
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
ENDOFFILE

import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.neural_network import MLPRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Combine train and test sets for preprocessing
combined = pd.concat([train, test], ignore_index=True)

# Drop unnecessary columns
columns_to_drop = ['Id', 'SalePrice']
y = combined['SalePrice'].dropna()
X = combined.drop(columns=columns_to_drop)

# Handle missing values
X.fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

# Encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X)

# Scale numerical features
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

# Split back into train and test sets
X_train = X_scaled[:len(train)]
X_test = X_scaled[len(train):]

# Define the model
nn_model = MLPRegressor(hidden_layer_sizes=(100,), max_iter=500, random_state=42)

# Train the model
nn_model.fit(X_train, y)

# Make predictions
predictions = nn_model.predict(X_test)

# Debug print to check the shape and contents of predictions
print("Predictions shape:", predictions.shape)
print("Predictions sample:", predictions[:5])

# Ensure predictions are of float type
predictions = predictions.astype(float)

# Save predictions to submission.csv
submission = pd.DataFrame({'Id': test['Id'], 'SalePrice': predictions})
submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
ENDOFFILE

import pandas as pd
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from sklearn.neural_network import MLPRegressor
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.metrics import mean_squared_error

# Load data
train = pd.read_csv('data/train.csv')
test = pd.read_csv('data/test.csv')

# Combine train and test sets for preprocessing
combined = pd.concat([train, test], ignore_index=True)

# Drop unnecessary columns
columns_to_drop = ['Id', 'SalePrice']
y = combined['SalePrice'].dropna()
X = combined.drop(columns=columns_to_drop)

# Handle missing values
X.fillna(method='ffill', inplace=True)

# Encode categorical variables
X = pd.get_dummies(X)

# Scale numerical features
scaler = StandardScaler()
X_scaled = scaler.fit_transform(X)

# Split back into train and test sets
X_train = X_scaled[:len(train)]
X_test = X_scaled[len(train):]

# Define the model

# Train the model

# Make predictions

# Debug print to check the shape and contents of predictions

# Ensure predictions are of float type

# Save predictions to submission.csv

submission.to_csv('submission.csv', index=False)
